Award.AwardTitle: A community building workshop on Energy, Earth and Environmental Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Use of energy is largely responsible for the economic power of the United States and the prosperity and well being of its citizens. As America is increasing its production of renewable energy, it is important for college students to learn about energy sources, energy use and how to maximize the benefits and reduce the problems associated with energy use. However, the subject of energy and the environment is so large that it often goes beyond the knowledge of any one professor. Professors and students from different backgrounds will come together for a one-day workshop to share their knowledge and develop better ways of teaching students about energy and its uses and the consequences of these uses.

To help advance the convergence among the interdisciplinary fields of energy, Earth and environmental education, the National Association of Geoscience Teachers and the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences will hold the first Energy, Earth and Environmental Education community-building workshop as part of the 2019 AESS Conference at the University of Central Florida. Energy, Earth, environmental and other educators and students in K-12, higher education, and informal education will share best practices and develop new partnerships. The agenda will include classroom issues (content, curriculum, pedagogy and connections between theory and practice) and programs (degree and sub-degree programs) to be explored primarily in small group presentations and discussion. Each session will develop options and examples for integrating energy, Earth and environmental education that will be presented in a report and on a public website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Use of energy is largely responsible for the economic power of the United States and the prosperity and well-being of its citizens. However, the types of energy (such as fossil fuels and nuclear energy) that are used and the amounts that are being used damage the environment and damage the health and well-being of some people. America is increasing its production of renewable energy. It is important for college students to learn about energy sources, energy use and how to maximize the benefits and reduce the problems associated with energy use. However, the subject of energy and the environment is so large that it often goes beyond the knowledge of any one professor.

The National Association of Geoscience Teachers (NAGT) in partnership with the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences (AESS) held a community-building workshop on Energy, Earth and Environmental Education (E4) as part of the 2019 AESS Conference. The workshop took place on June 26, 2019 at the University of Central Florida.  More than thirty professors and teachers and college students and ten high school students from different backgrounds relating to energy, Earth and the environment came together for a one-day workshop to share their knowledge and develop better ways of teaching students about energy and its uses and the consequences of these uses. Participants responded to surveys immediately after the workshop and seven months later. A community survey of 116 educators in Earth and environmental education identified further needs in E4.

More than 67% of the participants in the follow up survey responded that they changed their teaching as a result of the workshop. These changes included: ?I reorganized my environmental science course to focus completely around climate change?; ?More emphasis upon sustainability links to energy production, particularly upon near-term energy technologies available for community sustainability planning?; ?Through talking with other graduate programs, we proposed some other experiential programs that we could provide students in our program outside of the classroom?. Half of the respondents initiated professional contact with someone who they met at the workshop.

Nearly all (91%) of the community participants stated that energy is a very important environmental issue and 88% stated a desire for NAGT and AESS to promote connections among energy, Earth and environmental sciences. The community survey that followed the workshop identified the following needs as priorities:

  • Promote development of teaching tools (curricula, PowerPoints, maps, books, etc.)
  • Create and maintain a content library (case studies, TED talks, activities, etc.)
  • Develop a teacher?s guide for teaching about energy
  • Provide professional development workshops on teaching about energy
